message_text: What did you find interesting about gamification as described in the article?The part that stuck out to me the most was the fourth paragraph under "How: Goals and Techniques": "It [gamification] gives students clear, actionable tasks and promises them immediate rewards instead of vague long-term benefits...Games maintain this positive relationship with failure by making feedback cycles rapid and keeping the stakes low...in schools, on the other hand, the stakes of failure are high and the feedback cycles long. Students have few opportunities to try, and when they do, it is high stakes."This resonated with me particularly in my experience with high-risk students where it's almost impossible to make them believe that school can help them succeed in life - the payoff is just too far away to make sense when there are all sorts of immediate gains that come from taking school less seriously, and they don't have to risk feeling stupid, particularly if they are already behind academically. Is gamification what you thought it was?I have read a little bit about gamification in the past, so Lee and Hammer's description fit with what I thought gamification was. How does gamification differ from actually using games? Gamification is using the techniques of games in a different context. It can mean turning an assignment into a game, but it can also refer to adding a "game component", like a competitive or cooperative element to the assignment. I think there is a lot of nuance around gamification and actually making it work in schools that will have to be discovered by trial and error. Gamification is a lot more than just switching from "grades" to "experience points", leaving everything else the same, and expecting student's motivation to be transformed. It required a much more in depth knowledge of what makes games appealing.I think a lot of the fun of games come from not being mandatory. So that's a hard line to draw in implementing gamification since we want all students to participate and we are accountable for them as teachers. I was thinking about our online learning community and how the book suggested (and Instructor has modeled this) that the community have places both for the required academic discussions/assignments, but also places for more causal, social interaction. Perhaps that is a lesson that could benefit gamification - in a classroom there could be certain games (or parts of a larger game) that are required, but there are also games (or areas of the larger game) that are low-stakes and just for fun. Students can get drawn in to the low-stakes game and work their way up to something more overtly educational.

O,You've hit on what intrigues me most about gamification, I think--redefining what success in school looks like and feels like. Games encourage repeating a level until you master it, and then moving on--and that's defined as normal and good. How do we do that in schools?

Thanks for your thoughts, O.I agree with you - "A lot of the fun of games come from not being mandatory." Gamification, though, is about implementing gaming elements into the learning environment and activities, which can create a fun environment for the student that relates to the casual gamer.

O- I agree with your thoughts in the first paragraph that it can be hard to keep students going when the outcome it so far away.  The article seem to really support the idea that gaming helps to keep students not only interested, but also helps to develop endurance.  The ability to keep at a task until you have success is a great life long skill.

I for sure see the potential for gamification in schools as described in the article and that schools already have some gamification in play (e.g., grades).  However, I like how they point out that grades and such are always high-stakes, whereas with games the stakes are always within reach and you get multiple chances to learn from failures.  Most importantly, I like the idea of returning fun to the learning.  When I was teaching high school I always had my students take a look at William Glasserês choice theory.  I would ask them when and how they get their various needs fulfilled.  Fun was always the tough one because most of the time fun was only had outside of school, but inevitably Iêd always find some students who craved this need so much in school that they would behave inappropriately.  It always came down to lake of time to be social.  Every time.  So, as a teacher what do you do with that?  I worked hard to create assignments or activities that forced my students to cooperate and sometimes compete, not always with success, but I found when I did give time for them to be social it paid off in terms of cutting down poor behavior.  However, itês a tough one because you only have so much time and lots of content to get through.I have read some of James Geeês work on gamification for other classes, so I was a little familiar with it prior to reading this article.  I am for sure intrigued about how to gamify aspects of school.  However, I do worry about the potential to fall into the extrinsic reward trap.  I think the interesting work will be to look into that line or space or whatever it is where young people (and adults) move away from the extrinsic reward and do it because they either enjoy it or made a commitment to it or they know they are learning from it or simply put, see value in it.  As I said, in my FlipGrid, I myself participate daily in to activities that use badges and rewards and even though itês a bit silly they do motivate me, but ultimately I do it because I see value in doing it.Gamification is the using of gaming techniques, not the game itself. I like how the authors argue, _a well-designed gamification system can help players take on meaningful roles that are fruitful for learning. By making the development of a new identity playful, and by rewarding it appropriately, we can help students think differently about their potential in school and what school might mean for them?(p. 4).  So, we can make school not this _game?that we all know and dread that we must get through to get to those potential rewards (e.g., graduation), but rather this game where you can try on new things safely and change constantly.  Iêm excited for it because gamification can foster curiosity, creativity, and ultimately can allow those involved to change the game itself.  Therefore, I see a lot more fluidity in gamification whereas the actual game is more set with specific rules and norms.

I love what you say about changing school from a game students dread to a game that fosters their curiosity and creativity, one they themselves can help change--very well put!

What did you find interesting about gamification as described in the article? "Educational gamification proposes the use of game-like rule systems, player experiences and cultural roles to shape learners?behavior." I thought it was interesting that the act of playing the game was the focus. One big question I had was how well do the problem-solving skills and persistence transfer into non-game based learning situations? The authors acknowledge that having students learn only through external rewards might be one of the drawbacks but I wonder to what extent students can integrate/apply this type of learning more broadly. For example, the article indicates that gamification, "gives students clear, actionable tasks and promises the immediate rewards instead of vague long-term benefits." What happens when a student has to solve a messy, ill-structured problem? Is gamification what you thought it was? I assumed it was game-based learning. I'm a little confused as to whether it is a specific type of game-based learning. I wasn't certain what the characterisitcs of "gamification" vs  other "game-based learning" would be. Does it always need to have immediate reward systems? And to what extent are the cultural roles described critical? I was surprised that the authors used Angry Birds as an example of gamification learning.How does gamification differ from actually using games? I would think that effective gamification would have the learning objectives critical to the game play. I wondered whether good gamification design would provide means of scaffolding the learning to situations outside of the game. I also wondered if gamification design could mitigate the negative aspects such as game addiction so that it is still engaging but does not become a harmful escape.

Thanks for your thoughts, E.  Problem-solving skills and persistence do transfer into non-gaming environments as well. Problem-based learning is a great example of a situation that may be a non-gaming environment. Basically, students learn about a subject through problem-solving activities. Usually, in problem-based learning environments, students work collaboratively to solve a problem, and it creates a high level of self motivation. Gamification takes the elements of games (points, rewards, external motivation, fun) to increase student engagement and motivation. I suggest checking out the following from a presentation at a conference last year: http://sloanconsortium.org/conference/2013/et4online/hiding-broccol....

Instead, games have probability to distract students?attention from course content to game environment.

What did you find interesting about gamification as described in the article? _The most dramatic example of emotional transformation in a game is around the issue of failure. Because games involve repeated experimentation, they also involve repeated failure. In fact, for many games, the only way to learn how to play the game is to fail at it repeatedly, learning something each time (Gee, 2008). Games maintain this positive relationship with failure by making feedback cycles rapid and keeping the stakes low. The former means players can keep trying until they succeed; the latter means they risk very little by doing so. In schools, on the other hand, the stakes of failure are high and the feedback cycles long. Students have few opportunities to try, and when they do, it is high stakes. Little wonder that students experience anxiety, not anticipation, when offered the chance to fail (Pope, 2003).?Failure has been a common theme in my life for good and bad reasons. However, what I can take away from most of my experiences that most were not life altering and only life adjusting.  It is my strong belief, and supported with personal evidence, that without failure we donêt learn anything, we donêt push ourselves harder; we donêt reflection on our practice and identify what went wrong. However, in our schools, time is our greatest enemy. Students donêt have time to redo assignments or try something again most times without the hassles of trying to work on material from the past and present concurrently. I have found that my students will focus so much on creating finished works without allowing for the creative process to occur when working on projects. They want to get it right the first time without any experimentation and when it doesnêt look exactly like they want it to, they give up. Our students lack that piece that engages them, pulls them in and pushes their beliefs. We may even want to include another go to word: GRIT. They also control each otherês online behavior.  For a while one participant was being naughty and the author only had to _talk?once to this kid. As I read it, I thought of _brick and mortar?type schools using gamification strategies in teaching and learning, not necessarily online learning environments.  I really like the idea of gamifying school when possible because I do believe it can make space for creativity and foster curiosity.  I was pretty sold in the _framework social gamification: guidelines and objectives?section, but when I got to _4.3 descriptive scenario?I have to admit I was let down.  I guess I felt like this potential scenario really only took activities you might already do in class, put them online, and made grades more visible.  I did not see the neat features of gamification that allow players to adapt or find a different route to success as described in the framework.  To me it felt like what already happens in school, just more public.  I want to see more space where students can interact and collaborate.  Let me give you an example. I think this is really an interesting question. I think gamification can definitely enhance a student's learning in an actual school setting but I am not certain it would enhance an online learning community in the same way. I have been in many different classrooms in the past couple of years where gamification has been used. Part of the learning experience that I have seen occur with students happened with the social interactions while playing the game.  For example I was recently in a 6th grade classroom where they were playing a game to learn about how the election works in the United States. They were the person running to be President and had to go around campaigning in order to win the election. During the game the kids would be talking to one another and explaining how they did things in order to win a state. This helped their learning experiences because they were able to bounce off ideas from one another and learn from each others mistakes. When it comes to gamification online, I think it would be more difficult to have this type of interaction with others because you would have to almost stop what you were doing every time you go stuck or needed help. I do think if there was a way you could interact with somebody without having to stop and type out what you needed help with that gamification could definitely enhancing learning in an online learning community.

I think that depending on the grade level for incorporating gamification in online communities, it definitely could enhance online learning within communities.  Gamification provides an outlet to a interactive and creative type of mindset.  I would argue that gamification might not work for every student.  Some individuals prefer not read fiction novels for example, and based off of what I have read about gamification--it seems to be very creative and fiction oriented.  I think that for online communities to occur, an individual always has a choice to participate/join.  If the gamification setting is apparent in an online college, related course--students will either like this idea and register, or not like the way it is set up and not join.  For required elementary level courses I would be careful because the teacher wouldn't want to stray too far from the intial content of the class and subject.  I think the right level of creativity/rules/expectations for students is important.  A nice balance of these details would hopefully result in a successful, working online community.

I agree with your observation that gamification might not be suitable as a learning tool for every student. I want to go further to say that it might not be suitable for every subject; for example, accounting and finance.

It is still too early to answer affirmatively that gamification enhances learning for all students. It appears that gamification has the potential to improve learning for K-12 students. This is the generation that grew up with video games and are quite comfortable in such a virtual world. In my own family, my grandson started watching video games on iPad at an early age. Without reading the icons on a computer he knows the links to his favorable programs. He is not afraid to try various things on the iPad. Such a child will be quite comfortable using gamification for learning. I wonder, though, whether he will see it as an intellectual or learning activity. I am not sure I agree with the gentleman who gave the TED talk on gamification. He believes that the days of reading books and newspaper are over, and gamification is the future. He encourages parents to get in the game business with their children. I would be rather cautious about writing a premature obituary for books and newspaper, however. Videos or any other technological tools should be viewed as means to achieve learning, but the tools themselves are not the learning. Perhaps we should be asking whether contents are are these kinds learning when they use gamification. One concern I have as a parent about kinds' a deep immersion with gamification is the social isolation that it engenders. My grandson can be so consumed with video games that he does not want to eat or talk. We have had to impose a strict time limit on him. Too much exposure to gamification will lead to other unintended social problems in the future.

You raise some excellent points, N. Games and video games do create social isolation when the user chooses not to interact with those around him/her. Is there any research results that show too much exposure to games creates future social problems?

Thanks, C, for your question about whether video games cause future social problems. I was limiting my comments to my grandson who is beginning to exhibit social isolation due to what is appearing to be too much exposure to his iPad. Some of the shows he watches are video games, although I need to point out that he has not yet played video games. I have not read research that links video games to future social problems directly. What I do know is that there is good research studies indicating that distance education students exhibit high drop-out rates due to social isolation (Lee, M. J. W., & Chan, A. (2007). Reducing the effects of isolation and promoting inclusivity for distance learners through podcasting. Turkish Online Journal of Distance Education, 8(1); Kanuka, H., Jugdev, K., Heller, R., & West, D. (2008). The rise of the teleworker: false promises and responsive solutions. Higher Education, 56, 149-165; Dow, M. J. (2008). Implications of Social Presence for Online Learning: A Case Study of MLS Students. Journal for Library and Information Science, 49(4), 231-242; Earl, K. (2013). Student views on short-text assignment formats in fully online.

Hi N,I'm glad you brought up the TED talk.  I also did not agree with the man on the TED talk.  My girls, particularly my almost 11 year old, loves to read a good old fashioned book and will do so for hours.  Her grandma gave her a Kindle (the super basic one) and she still prefers to go get books at the library.  She will download a library book to her Kindle only when she is done reading the actual books.  Her friends and her share books too.  So, I don't think days of paper backs or newspapers are actually over either.

Hi N, I am so impressed by your comments! I agree with you that the tools or technologies themselves are not the learning. They are means to achieve better learning and the key element is learners themselves. How they use these tools and technologies, including games. For kids, they are not mature enough to control the time they spend on gaming or they are not mature enough to really guide themselves to learn something from gaming. So, as far as I am concerned,  in this "Gamification" learning process, parents' and teachers' guide and management are important.

Do you think gamification enhances online learning communities? Why or why not? As my experience with gamification doesn't extend past the content that I have taken in over the last week, I am indeed intrigued about the concept and the role this game structure has played in my life. I am not extremely competitive, but when presented with an opportunity to gain badges or stock pile cash in my Pocket Trains app, I have no problem watching the hours tick by. There is potential to keep individuals engaged in the practice of online learning communities by bringing in these elements from game structure, but the research proposal we read left much to be desired in the way of direct research and an articulated focus outside of general suggestions. Another concern is the understanding the motivation of the individual. As I mentioned, the flashy badges might hook me in from the beginning, but the ability to sustain community might be questionable. Motivation becomes an important consideration whether the individuals are intrinsically or extrinsically influenced. A competitive nature does not apply to all, but again this is only one facet of the gamification framework. As a parent of two small children who also are "digital natives" I am concerned about the world they are going to be a part of in the not so near future. My oldest will be starting kindergarten next year and with tools mentioned like schooools.com I was intrigued about the possible benefits that might have with him. He loves using the iPad and loves the incentives that come about with beating a character on Mr. Crab, but the addictive nature of the game may not bode well for his lack of self-control. I agree with N that we need to be careful in how we roll these technologies and to what age groups.
